The only hardware aspect I really care for is battery life and that is strongly tied to efficient software or the lack thereof. I install something that promised to filter out blue light and will also dim the screen, saving lots and lots of battery life this way. Ironically Android constantly reports this app as eating battery in the background, when it does exactly the opposite. I can go days without charging, despite normal use. 

Also, the screen needs to be big. I'm especially disappointed by the small width. Phones increase in height, which doesn't matter to me, but they are kind of stuck at their current width. 

A headphone jack is a must. Wireless headphones are too easy to lose. 

Don't do the stupid notch thing. As I said, screen estate in height is pointless.

My hands are big enough to even use a small tablet one handed like a phone. 
Blue light triggers our brains to be awake. They use it inside long tunnels, for example. Blue light also makes everything brighter. If you've got one of those LEDs where you can switch the color around, try it at night to switch from red to blue and see how much brighter the entire room gets.

Filtering blue light in the evening out of your screens helps with sleep, since blue light constantly signals our brain to be alert/awake. For phone screens there's the additional benefit of not attracting mosquitoes and other bugs with the screen light. Bugs will naturally fly towards blue light. (White light contains blue light.)

Blue light filters are part of the defaults nowadays, even Win10 has one build in. A pretty good one at that. But the ones for phones are lousy, so I use an app that is better at this. The downside is that I have to turn it off in bright sun light.

I guess the biggest problem with projects like these is that you are essentially crafting ghost towns, by copying an infrastructure designed to scale up for millions of people, but not designed to scale down to accommodate a dozen. 

Voat on the clearnet has the same issue, and basically lives off the people reddit bans. It's somewhat like people new to Linux trying to recreate their Windows workflows. 

To take off, being a copy won't be good enough.  There needs to be some value to attract people. The value of reddit isn't the infrastructure, but the content the people contribute. But I don't know how to solve this chicken-egg-proglem.

Trust is difficult to gain, but easy to lose. It's the default attitude for people living in society. For example, it's a natural thing for people traveling by train to help others with their luggage. But if this trust is ever exploited to rob them, this natural trust gets replaced by wariness. 

That's the advantage of the clearnet. It operates on people's default trust. But it's an uphill battle to gain the trust of the people that got their trust betrayed. Which is pretty much all of them, but not everyone has realized yet. Only the ones that realized will show up around these parts, though.

So now the question is how to trust anything on the Internet again. I don't have an answer for this.

But manipulative algorithms is only scratching the surface of things. It's much more comprehensive than that. Reflect on the things you read on the Internet and try to evaluate whether it can be trusted. Like a review on a popular internet shop. Bad or good, it is certain that a large percentage of them are paid for to manipulate your impression. Can you tell which are genuine and which are not? Or a news report. Same story. Can you distinguish truth from lie? Or an online forum. Same exact thing. It's impossible to tell for sure which are genuine people and which are paid shills. Even worse, AI has gotten good enough to become really, really difficult to tell apart from fellow humans. Most people even lack the basic awareness that AI, that is hard to distinguish from humans is a thing that exists. Manipulators have easily scalable methods to reach most people. Even without the AI, there are services where you can buy real humans doing this thing for you and it's possibly even cheaper than the AI solution.

Once you realize the dilemma, how can you ever trust anything on the Internet again? Verifying everything personally doesn't scale and often isn't possible at all. Just take a common example from recent years. X raped Y. How would you even go about verifying this claim?

That's where I'm stuck. How do you reliably tell truth from lies?

Is this even a problem that is solvable on the technical side of things? Software is even harder to trust, since it's always just one update away from being compromised. And the updates for these kind of things come really, really fast. 

Don't get me wrong. I like that this project exists. It's a 'something'. All I'm doing is talking, which usually doesn't accomplish anything. It's just that I'm seeing little hope for the reasons I stated.  I'd say nevermind the trust issue and let's focus on providing some value, but the trust issue might be the most crucial thing in this context. Since ignoring it, you might as well just set up shop on the clearnet.

You'd need something quite different from reddit that prevents communities from forming, while still providing a similar service. The parallel universe theory is just one attempt to resolve the first time travel paradox. But it cannot fully resolve the paradox. Say you travel from the year 2020 of timeline A back to the year 2019, reach timeline B and kill yourself. A parallel universe resolves the paradox of killing your previous self, but what if you wait two years in timeline B and than travel back to the year 2020 of timeline A, only to kill yourself before going out on your adventure. The paradox is back. 

It's like resolving the origin of life by saying life came from outer space. It doesn't resolve anything, it just introduced indirection.

As an addendum, if you want to resolve the paradox by establishing the rule, that each time you time-travel you create a new parallel universe, so you wouldn't be able to go back to your original timeline A, after having traveled to timeline B, you make time-travel completely meaningless, since that would mean no time-traveler could ever reach our timeline A.

I don't bother with politics. I'm here because the tech is cool and I think the centralized Internet is flawed. Take Google for example. They make money with ads, so when you search for something, sites that use Google Ads magically appear at the top. 

Centralization is easy, but creates power structures that are then easy to abuse. Think about YouTube. All the content is there, so everyone searching for a video will go to YouTube. Now if you're a video creator, where do you upload? Where the eyeballs are. So now YouTube has become the only viable choice to both watch and upload videos to. 

If instead there were many video sites and many search sites that each would let you search over all of them, wouldn't that be better for everyone involved? Power wouldn't concentrate into few people's hands and therefore abuse opportunities wouldn't arise. 

Same thing with Microsoft, Apple's AppStore, Steam, Netflix etc. etc. etc. 

Centralization gives power to the platform owners which is then easy to abuse. 

Governments are no exception. Wouldn't it be way better for everyone if the USA and the European Union just disbanded? World Government is stupid. Countries should be smaller. People all over the world are different and it's easier to satisfy everyone's needs and wants if there aren't so many opinions to considerate.
